content:
It sounds like you had a great time on your hunting trip, even if you didn't harvest a deer. Seeing fresh buck rubs near your tree stand is definitely a promising sign, and it's exciting to think about the possibilities for the upcoming rifle season.

It's also great that you were able to spend quality time with your parents and help out with some chores around the property. There's something special about working together with family members on tasks that benefit the property and the community. Fixing a broken fence post and splitting firewood are important tasks that require some elbow grease, but they're also opportunities to bond and create memories with your loved ones.

It's also wonderful that you have a family cabin on the property where you can retreat to and enjoy some peace and quiet. Being in nature, surrounded by trees and wildlife, can be incredibly rejuvenating and help clear the mind.

Did you learn anything new or gain any insights from your hunting trip? For example, did you try out any new gear or tactics, or did you learn more about the behavior of the deer in the area?

Also, are you planning to head back to the property for the rifle season, or will you be hunting in a different location?
